Monetary developments in the euro area (Aug 2018) https://t.co/3SYpYLu5Ys

What is more, the simulation shows unambiguously that an economy imposing a tariff which prompts retaliation by other countries is worse off. Its living standards fall and jobs are lost. See our latest Economic Bulletin for more https://t.co/HY92UdAtR2 4/4

The results: higher tariffs could have major adverse global effects, stemming from: 1) the impact they would have on imports and exports, and related effects such as firms investing less and hiring fewer workers; and 2) uncertainty and weakened financial market confidence. 3/4 https://t.co/PnA3qZ349M

What if trade tensions escalate? How would this affect the global economy? We tested a hypothetical scenario in which the US raises tariffs on all imports by 10 percentage points and its trading partners respond by imposing the same tariffs on the US (but not on each other). 2/4

Economic Bulletin Issue 6, 2018

Web version https://t.co/1b5guhC4JE

PDF https://t.co/Fjee9ZJnAK

Speech Peter Praet: Challenges to monetary policy normalisation https://t.co/iqajil5VgG
Mario Draghi: The lesson is clear: when Europe focuses on common challenges, when it recognises interdependence, and when it responds with appropriate institutions, it succeeds. 7/7

Mario Draghi: We know that even sound domestic policies are not always enough. This is why there is also a role for public risk-sharing, although the more we complete banking union and capital markets union, the smaller this needs to be. 6/7

Mario Draghi: National fiscal policies should be made more effective by encouraging governments to build up buffers. For that, we need to rekindle faith in our fiscal rules by making them both more countercyclical and more binding. 5/7

Mario Draghi: First, we need to address the obstacles to deeper financial integration. This includes finishing the clean-up of bank balance sheets and removing the remaining supervisory and regulatory barriers that hamper cross-border activity. 4/7

Mario Draghi: European leaders of the 1980s understood that low growth was a common challenge and that the Single Market was a powerful tool to address it. Today, we should re-establish a clear focus on completing the Single Market in all its dimensions. 3/7
Mario Draghi: The challenges we face in Europe today are in many ways similar to those of the 1980s and many of them have weak growth performance at their root. 2/7
